text.p: The following are some of the leading stories in Russian newspapers this morning. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
IZVESTIA
- Georgian President Eduard Shevardnadze and separatist Abkhaz leader Vladislav Ardzinba have signed an agreement banishing the use of military force in settling disputes.
- The Pentagon is exerting pressure on Sofia to get rid of a secret Russian-made air-defence system deployed in Bulgaria since 1984.
- Rebel Tajik military commander Makhmud Khudoyberdyev has refused to give up his arms to government troops.

- The appointment of Interfax news agency's director Mikhail Komissar to the post of deputy head of President Boris Yeltsin's administration indicates the Russian leadership is willing to pay more attention to public relations.
- The Interior Ministry and the Justice Ministry continue their tug-of-war over who will control the Russian penitentiary system.
- Russian civil aviation security standards are in sharp decline.
- Two Russian cosmonauts who returned to Earth on Thursday will now come under close scrutiny of a special commission investigating the hitches and mishaps that dogged the 186-day mission.
- Tokyo is working to improve its political relations with Moscow so they will not be outdone by other countries hoping to share in Russia's economic pie.
KOMMERSANT DAILY
- A number of oil companies, including Rosneft and Tyumen Oil company, are to be auctioned in autumn, says Maxim Boiko, Russia's new privatisation chief.
- Russia's president and the government are determined to create a realistic 1998 budget.
- According to a new privatisation policy, individual regulations will be worked out for auctioning big state stakes, says Alexander Livshits, deputy head of President Yeltsin's administration.

- If the Mir orbiting station fails to dock with the Progress M-35 cargo ship, then docking with the U.S. shuttle scheduled for September would be impossible. This would be the end of U.S.-Russia cooperation in space.
- Russia's State Customs Committe is likely to transfer its accounts from commercial banks to Central Bank.
SEVODNYA
- The International Monetary Fund (IMF) may hold up the next $700 million tranche of the EFF loan to Russia if the government fails to control the volume of money circulating in the country.
- President Yeltsin is taking big privatisation auctions under his personal control.
- At the State Duma, the lower house of Russian parliament, experts and oil producers continue their debate on the new tax code.
NEZAVISIMAYA GAZETA
- The meeting between Russian President Yeltsin and the leader of Chechnya is unlikely to be fruitful, the paper says.
ROSSIISKAYA GAZETA
- The appointment of Maxim Boiko head of the State Property Committee does not mean fundamentals of privatisation will change, says First Deputy Prime Minister Anatoly Chubais.
- The crew of the Mir station just returned from space will have to give an account for all the accidents that happened aboard the run-down spacecraft during their mission.

- Commercial banks in charge of handling budget funds most often carry out their duties with care and the decision to transfer state funds to the Central Bank appears to be mainly of political nature, says Deputy Chairman of the Bank of Russia Alexander Khandruyev.
MOSKOVSKY KOMSOMOLETS
- Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin has praised his government on having worked out a viable 1998 draft budget.
- Rebel Tajik commander Khudoyberdyev seems to be alienated by all major political forces in the troubled republic.
-- Svetlana Kovaleva, Moscow Newsroom, +7095 941 8520
